cyclone.name: IAN
cyclone.current_location: about 220 miles SSE of Grand Cayman
cyclone.trajectory: Turning northwest tonight, then north-northwest Monday and north on Tuesday, tracking toward the eastern Gulf of Mexico and the west coast of Florida before crossing the peninsula and emerging into the Atlantic late in the work-week.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida west coast (likely near the Tampa Bay–Cedar Key region)

weather_observation.watch_coast: Lower Florida Keys from Seven Mile Bridge southward to Key West (not including Canaveral area)
weather_observation.warning_coast: None along Florida east coast at this time
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Florida peninsula, especially west coast, but tropical-storm impacts extend across central and eastern Florida including Canaveral area
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds are possible late Wednesday night through Thursday with a peak 38% chance of sustained 34-kt winds and gusts 45–55 mph.
weather_observation.storm_surge: No significant surge currently forecast for the Cape Canaveral area, though minor coastal inundation cannot be ruled out if the center exits into the Atlantic nearby.
weather_observation.rainfall: 2–4 inches widespread with locally up to 6 inches possible Wednesday–Thursday, producing risk of flash flooding and ponding around the port.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Outer rainbands may spawn brief tornadoes across east-central Florida; rough seas and dangerous rip currents expected beginning mid-week, impacting vessel operations.
